content.question:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="N 2, gas, plus 3 H 2, gas, are in equilibrium with 2 N H 3, gas. Delta H naught sub 298, equals negative 92.2 kilojoules per mole of reaction. Delta S naught sub 298, equals negative 198.8 joules per open parenthesis moles of reaction time kelvin close parenthesis." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>298</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>92.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>;</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>298</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>198.8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>/</mo><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>K</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) The reaction of <math alttext="N 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to form <math alttext="N H 3, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented above. The reaction has been studied in order to maximize the yield of <math alttext="N H 3, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) Calculate the value of <math alttext="delta G naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>k</mtext><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, at <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>.

(ii) Calculate the value of the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, at <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

frqParts.text:
For parts of the free response question that require calculations, clearly show the method used and the steps involved in arriving at your answers. You must show your work to receive credit for your answer. Examples and equations may be included in your answers where appropriate.

Answer the following questions related to <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="N 2, gas, plus 3 H 2, gas, are in equilibrium with 2 N H 3, gas. Delta H naught sub 298, equals negative 92.2 kilojoules per mole of reaction. Delta S naught sub 298, equals negative 198.8 joules per open parenthesis moles of reaction time kelvin close parenthesis." overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtable><mtr><mtd><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><mn>3</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mn>2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>298</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>92.2</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>;</mo></mrow></mtd><mtd><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>298</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup><mo>=</mo><mrow><mo>−</mo><mn>198.8</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>J</mtext><mtext> </mtext><mo>/</mo><mo>(</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>mol</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub><mo>⋅</mo><mtext>K</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mtd></mtr></mtable></mrow></mstyle></math>

(a) The reaction of <math alttext="N 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to form <math alttext="N H 3, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> is represented above. The reaction has been studied in order to maximize the yield of <math alttext="N H 3, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

(i) Calculate the value of <math alttext="delta G naught" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mi>°</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, in <math alttext="kilojoules per mole of reaction" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>k</mtext><mtext>J</mtext><mo>/</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>m</mtext><mtext>o</mtext><mtext>l</mtext></mrow><mrow><mi>r</mi><mi>x</mi><mi>n</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, at <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mn>298</mn><mspace width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></math>.

(ii) Calculate the value of the equilibrium constant, <math alttext="K sub p" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>, at <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext><mtext> </mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

Bond
 Average Bond Enthalpy <math alttext="(in kilojoules per mole)" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>(</mo><mtext>kJ</mtext><mo>/</mo><mtext>mol</mtext><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="N atom connected to a H atom by a single bond" overflow="scroll"><mtext>N</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>H</mtext></math>
 <math alttext="391" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>391</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="two H atoms connected by a single bond" overflow="scroll"><mtext>H</mtext><mo>−</mo><mtext>H</mtext></math>
 <math alttext="436" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>436</mn></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="two N atoms connected by a triple bond" overflow="scroll"><mtext>N</mtext><mo>≡</mo><mtext>N</mtext></math>
 <math alttext="question mark" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>?</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>

(b) Based on the average bond enthalpies in the table above and the value of <math alttext="delta H naught sub 298" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><msubsup><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>298</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>°</mo></mrow></msubsup></mrow></mstyle></math>, calculate the value of the <math alttext="two N atoms connected by a triple bond " overflow="scroll"><mtext>N</mtext><mo>≡</mo><mtext>N</mtext></math> bond enthalpy.

(c) Although the reaction is thermodynamically favorable at <math alttext="298 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>298</mn><mtext> </mtext><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mi>K</mi></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math>, it does not occur to an observable extent at this temperature. Explain how the <math alttext="two N atoms connected by a triple bond " overflow="scroll"><mtext>N</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.1em"></mspace><mo>≡</mo><mtext>N</mtext></math> bond enthalpy affects the rate of the reaction.

(d) The reaction is usually carried out at a very high temperature in the presence of a catalyst. Explain why the reaction is thermodynamically unfavorable at very high temperatures. Justify your answer in terms of <math alttext="delta H naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>H</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, <math alttext="delta S naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>S</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>, and their effect on <math alttext="delta G naught" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi mathvariant="normal">Δ</mi><mi>G</mi><mo>°</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>.

<math alttext="N 2, gas, plus 3 H 2, gas, are in equilibrium with 2 N H 3, gas" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>N</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>+</mo><msub><mrow><mtext>3</mtext><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo><mo>⇄</mo><mn>2</mn><msub><mrow><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.25em"></mspace><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math>
(e) Although the forward reaction represented above is thermodynamically unfavorable at very high temperatures, it can be used to produce <math alttext="N H 3 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> if the <math alttext="N H 3 " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> is continually removed from the reaction vessel. Explain in terms of <math alttext="Q" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>Q</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="K sub p " display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mi>K</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mi>p</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></math> why this method works.

The boiling points of <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> and <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> are given in the table below.

Substance
 Boiling Point

<math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="20 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>20</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

<math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math>
 <math alttext="240 kelvin" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>240</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>K</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>

(f) A student claims that <math alttext="H 2, gas " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> condenses at a much lower temperature than <math alttext="N H 3, gas" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub><mo>(</mo><mi>g</mi><mo>)</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> because <math alttext="H 2" overflow="scroll"><mrow><msub><mrow><mstyle><mrow><mtext>H</mtext></mrow></mstyle></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></math> has stronger intermolecular forces than <math alttext="N H 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mtext>NH</mtext></mrow><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> does. There are two errors in the student’s reasoning. Identify the student’s errors and explain your answer in terms of the specific types of forces involved.

skill.text: 4.A: Predict and/or explain chemical properties or phenomena (e.g., of atoms or molecules) using given chemical theories, models, and representations.
